products.name: Shopify Payments - D2C Plus, Shopify for ent, CCS

salesforce.ae_next_steps: [AS] 16.01 Technical discovery scheduled for 26.01 + intro to deal champion, Chris Turberville-Tulley

narratives.opp_summary: Moss Bros. Group Ltd is a £160M UK retailer evaluating Shopify Plus ($82,800 deal, $2.1M 3-year revenue impact) to replace their aging e-commerce platform (Remarkable) and legacy POS system (Dolphin). The evaluation is board-driven, with strategic directives to simplify a complex composable architecture, enable international expansion, and leverage AI — with a champion (Chris Turberville-Tully) actively building the case for a C-suite presentation targeted for early March 2026. This is a significantly more active deal than Salesforce data alone suggests, with 5 substantive discovery and technical calls completed since January 2026 and a tailored demo scheduled for the week of February 23rd.
narratives.why_change: Moss Bros. is running on two aging core systems — Remarkable for e-commerce and Dolphin for POS — both of which are failing to keep pace with the business. Remarkable is described as 'slow to adapt,' and the Dolphin POS system is aging to the point that replacing it is a top CEO/CFO priority. The company has invested heavily in a composable architecture (Zitec as middleware/CDP, OneStock for inventory), which has created significant complexity they want to simplify — they explicitly stated a need to 'uncomplicate their world.' Past security incidents have made the board acutely risk-averse and are now actively motivating a platform change. Operationally, their 'hire' business (suit rental with group bookings and deposits) and 'custom-made' business (bespoke tailoring/outfit builder) are fragmented across online and POS channels, creating inefficiency. The board and main shareholder are strategically questioning the current tech stack and have directed this evaluation.
narratives.why_shopify: Moss Bros. is drawn to Shopify for its unified commerce capabilities — the ability to consolidate e-commerce and POS onto a single platform, which directly addresses their core pain of managing disparate, aging systems. Chris Turberville-Tully is a self-described 'Shopify advocate' and is championing the platform to the CEO based on its simplicity, native integrations, and ability to reduce architectural complexity. The team expressed strong interest in Shopify's AI capabilities as a differentiator. They see Shopify as a way to consolidate disparate customer management systems and streamline their complex custom-made/outfit builder process across channels. International expansion support is also part of the strategic rationale, and Shopify Payments is being evaluated to replace Adyen as part of a broader simplification effort.
narratives.why_now: The evaluation is being driven by strategic board directives — the CEO and main shareholder are actively questioning the current technology stack and have mandated this review. The aging POS system (Dolphin) is a particularly urgent concern for the CEO and CFO, compounded by past security incidents that have heightened the board's appetite for change despite their risk-averse nature. There is a clear timeline forming: a technical demo review is scheduled for the week of February 23rd, with a C-suite presentation (CEO/CFO) targeted for early March 2026. While no hard contractual deadline has been mentioned, the board-level mandate and executive engagement suggest organizational momentum that could stall if not maintained.
narratives.support_needed: Handle complex 'hire' and 'custom-made' business model requirements — these are deal-critical (The Black Tux referenced as comparable). Address payment complexity and Adyen-to-Shopify Payments transition (split payments, deposits). Resolve average/weighted inventory costing question (raised multiple times). Provide implementation partner introductions (Chris requested 2-3 partners). Deliver case studies of similar UK retail migrations. Support Chris in overcoming Head of E-commerce resistance with an airtight business case. Provide realistic implementation timeline (flagged as critical by Joe). Clarify Zitec/OneStock integration approach — position around their existing investment, not against it.

questions.text: Do we know the business reasons driving the migration?
questions.notes: Multiple calls confirm: aging e-commerce (Remarkable) and POS (Dolphin) systems, need to simplify composable architecture, board directive, security concerns from past incidents, international expansion goals, desire to leverage AI. Call 2: 'uncomplicate their world.' Call 3: Chris confirms board-driven mandate.
questions.solution: N/A — well documented.
questions.action: N/A

questions.text: Do we have specific quantifiable goals?
questions.notes: £160M revenue company. D2C GMV of $39M and Payments GPV of $25.35M in Salesforce. No specific KPIs (conversion targets, TCO savings, cost reduction) articulated by the merchant.
questions.solution: Work with Chris to extract specific financial metrics from CFO — TCO savings, revenue uplift targets, operational cost reduction.
questions.action: Maissa to ask Chris for CFO's key financial metrics and success criteria during pre-exec prep.

questions.text: Has merchant confirmed current solution cannot achieve goals?
questions.notes: Current platforms (Remarkable, Dolphin) are aging and unable to support strategic goals. Remarkable is 'slow to adapt.' Dolphin POS replacement is a top CEO priority. Board has explicitly directed evaluation of alternatives.
questions.solution: N/A — confirmed.
questions.action: N/A

questions.text: Do we understand the impact if goals aren't achieved?
questions.notes: Security risk from past incidents understood. Fragmented customer experience across hire/custom-made/POS implied. No explicit quantification of cost of inaction.
questions.solution: Help Chris articulate the cost of inaction for the board presentation.
questions.action: Maissa to work with Chris to build a 'cost of doing nothing' slide for C-suite presentation.

questions.text: Is there a compelling event driving action?
questions.notes: Board directive driving evaluation. CEO/CFO engagement planned for early March. No hard contractual deadline (renewal, end-of-life). Urgency is strategic/political rather than contractual.
questions.solution: Probe whether Remarkable or Dolphin have contract renewal dates or end-of-support timelines.
questions.action: Maissa to ask Chris/Joe about Remarkable and Dolphin contract terms and hard deadlines.

questions.text: Have metrics been validated by the customer?
questions.notes: Specific quantifiable metrics not yet established. CFO not yet engaged directly. Chris mentioned gathering financial drivers from CFO but not confirmed completed.
questions.solution: Validate metrics with CFO during or before C-suite presentation.
questions.action: Maissa to confirm with Chris what financial data he's gathered from CFO and align on metrics.

questions.text: Are metrics compelling enough to justify change?
questions.notes: Qualitative case is strong — aging systems, security risk, board frustration, strategic expansion blocked. Without quantified metrics, unclear if business case survives CFO scrutiny with risk-averse board.
questions.solution: Build quantified ROI model showing TCO comparison, operational savings, and revenue upside.
questions.action: Maissa/Sarah to prepare preliminary ROI framework for Chris to validate with CFO data.

questions.text: Have you identified who can spend unbudgeted funds?
questions.notes: Chris identified CEO and main shareholder as key decision-makers. CFO involvement confirmed for C-suite presentation. Unclear whether CEO, CFO, or shareholder holds final budget authority.
questions.solution: Clarify with Chris who specifically signs off on a platform investment of this size.
questions.action: Maissa to ask Chris: 'Who has final sign-off authority — CEO, CFO, or shareholder?'

questions.text: Do you know who will sign the contract?
questions.notes: Not discussed in any calls. Procurement process not explored.
questions.solution: Need to understand contract signing authority and process.
questions.action: Maissa to ask Chris about procurement/contract signing authority.

questions.text: Have you engaged directly with the EB?
questions.notes: No direct access to CEO, CFO, or shareholder yet. All engagement through Chris, Joe, and Brett. C-suite presentation in early March would be first direct access.
questions.solution: C-suite presentation is the vehicle — ensure it happens.
questions.action: Maissa to confirm C-suite presentation date with Chris. Push for pre-meeting if possible.

questions.text: Has champion provided a path to the EB?
questions.notes: Chris is actively arranging the C-suite presentation and committed to securing dates with CEO/CFO. He is positioned as champion with direct access to decision-makers.
questions.solution: N/A — path is clear.
questions.action: Follow up with Chris to confirm exec presentation is confirmed and not slipping.

questions.text: Do you know what the EB cares about?
questions.notes: Chris outlined CEO/CFO priorities: replacing aging POS, enhancing security, AI capabilities. These are Chris's interpretation — not validated directly with execs. Financial concerns (TCO, ROI, risk) likely important given 'risk-averse board.'
questions.solution: Validate these priorities directly with CEO/CFO during executive presentation.
questions.action: Maissa to prepare targeted discovery questions for CEO/CFO at exec meeting.

questions.text: Do you understand their budget process?
questions.notes: Decision-making process and budget allocation not discussed. Board is involved and risk-averse, but formal approval process unknown.
questions.solution: Map the decision process through Chris before the exec presentation.
questions.action: Maissa to ask Chris: 'Walk me through how a tech investment of this size gets approved.'

questions.text: Do we know how they will be making the decision?
questions.notes: Board is involved, C-suite presentation is a key milestone. Chris is building business case for CEO/CFO. Formal decision process (evaluation committee? board vote? RFP?) not clearly mapped.
questions.solution: Map the full decision process with Chris.
questions.action: Maissa to map end-to-end decision process with Chris: 'After the exec presentation, what happens next?'

questions.text: Do we know who's involved / buying committee?
questions.notes: Known: Chris (champion), Joe Castro (IT), Brett Grobler (IT), CEO, CFO, main shareholder. Head of E-commerce is resistant (potential blocker). No complete org chart or confirmed buying committee.
questions.solution: Build complete stakeholder map.
questions.action: Maissa to ask Chris for full list of people who will influence or approve this decision.

questions.text: Do we know when they want to decide?
questions.notes: No target decision date discussed. Salesforce close date 2026-09-30 appears to be a placeholder. Most concrete timeline is early March exec presentation.
questions.solution: Establish a target decision date with Chris.
questions.action: Maissa to ask Chris: 'What's the ideal timeline for making a platform decision?'

questions.text: Do we know what's driving the timeline?
questions.notes: Board directive driving urgency. No hard contractual or business deadline. Aging POS and security concerns create soft urgency. International expansion plans may have a timeline.
questions.solution: Probe for hard deadlines — contract renewals, fiscal year budgets, expansion launch dates.
questions.action: Maissa to ask about fiscal year timing, budget cycles, and hard deadlines.

questions.text: Have they tried to solve this before?
questions.notes: Previously evaluated Shopify but cost concerns were a barrier. Invested in Zitec as middleware to address data silos. Strategic board directives are now overriding past cost objections.
questions.solution: N/A — understood. Explore what changed since last Shopify evaluation.
questions.action: Maissa to explore: 'What's different this time vs. when Shopify was previously considered?'

questions.text: What happens if they maintain status quo?
questions.notes: Continued security risk, inability to expand internationally, fragmented customer experience, operational inefficiency. No explicit 'if we don't move, X happens by Y date.'
questions.solution: Help Chris articulate cost of inaction for business case.
questions.action: Include cost-of-inaction analysis in executive presentation business case.

questions.text: Has the decision process been validated?
questions.notes: Decision process not fully mapped, so not validated with economic buyer. Chris has described it directionally but CEO/CFO haven't confirmed.
questions.solution: Validate process during or before C-suite meeting.
questions.action: Maissa to confirm decision process with Chris and ask him to validate with CEO.

questions.text: Do we know their evaluation criteria?
questions.notes: Key criteria from calls: POS replacement, security, AI, hire/custom-made handling, payment complexity, inventory costing, implementation timeline, Zitec/OneStock integration. No formal evaluation criteria or RFP shared.
questions.solution: Ask Chris if there's formal criteria or help define one.
questions.action: Maissa to ask Chris: 'Has the board defined formal evaluation criteria? Can we help structure that?'

questions.text: Have we discussed all capabilities?
questions.notes: D2C e-commerce discussed. POS discussed extensively. Omnichannel discussed. B2B not discussed — unclear if relevant.
questions.solution: Confirm B2B relevance; ensure demo covers full omnichannel vision.
questions.action: Sarah to confirm B2B relevance with Joe/Chris and ensure demo covers omnichannel.

questions.text: Have we surfaced technical complications?
questions.notes: Extensively discussed: Zitec/OneStock integration, Adyen-to-Shopify Payments transition, average inventory costing, complex hire business logic, custom-made/outfit builder workflow, split payment logic.
questions.solution: N/A — well-surfaced. Now need to address them.
questions.action: Sarah to ensure all technical complications have clear answers for the demo.

questions.text: Do we know how payments play into decision?
questions.notes: Currently on Adyen with complex split payment logic and deposits. Shopify Payments is part of evaluation. Joe raised split payment concerns. $25.35M GPV.
questions.solution: Ensure payments transition story is clear and compelling.
questions.action: Sarah to prepare Adyen vs. Shopify Payments comparison addressing split payments and deposits.

questions.text: Is there a mutual action plan?
questions.notes: Informal plan: demo review week of Feb 23 → exec presentation early March. Chris coordinating dates. No formal MAP with milestones beyond March.
questions.solution: Formalize a MAP with Chris.
questions.action: Maissa to draft mutual action plan and review with Chris after demo review.

questions.text: Have we shaped the decision criteria?
questions.notes: Actively shaping conversation around unified commerce, AI, POS modernization, simplification. Demo being tailored. Head of E-commerce (resistant) may define criteria favoring status quo.
questions.solution: Help Chris define criteria that favor Shopify's strengths.
questions.action: Maissa to provide Chris a suggested evaluation framework highlighting Shopify advantages.

questions.text: Do we know who defined the criteria?
questions.notes: No formal criteria shared. Unclear whether board, CEO, Head of E-commerce, or Chris is defining 'success.' Head of E-commerce resistance creates risk of unfavorable criteria.
questions.solution: Understand who's setting criteria and ensure alignment.
questions.action: Maissa to ask Chris: 'Who will define the evaluation criteria? Can we get ahead of that?'

questions.text: Do we know their procurement process?
questions.notes: Not discussed in any calls. No information on procurement, legal review, or contract processes.
questions.solution: Start mapping procurement process early.
questions.action: Maissa to ask Chris about procurement/contracting process.

questions.text: Are there likely to be redlines?
questions.notes: Risk-averse board and past security incidents suggest legal/security redlines are likely. £160M company will have procurement and legal processes.
questions.solution: Anticipate security/data protection clauses early.
questions.action: Maissa to flag to Shopify legal that security will be scrutinized. Pre-prepare documentation.

questions.text: How long does legal review take?
questions.notes: Not discussed.
questions.solution: Map when procurement process is explored.
questions.action: Include in procurement discovery conversation with Chris.

questions.text: What is the overall procurement timeline?
questions.notes: No procurement timeline discussed. Close date of 2026-09-30 may account for this.
questions.solution: Establish realistic procurement timeline.
questions.action: Maissa to include paper process timeline in mutual action plan.

questions.text: Have contract details been discussed?
questions.notes: No contract discussed. Deal is in Envision stage.
questions.solution: Premature — focus on business case first.
questions.action: Prepare contract framework once executive buy-in is secured.

questions.text: Has a contract been sent?
questions.notes: Too early in the process.
questions.solution: N/A at this stage.
questions.action: N/A

questions.text: Is there a target signature date?
questions.notes: Not discussed. Salesforce close date 2026-09-30 not validated.
questions.solution: Work backwards from desired go-live.
questions.action: Maissa to ask Chris about desired go-live date.

questions.text: What are their current pain points?
questions.notes: Extensively documented: aging Remarkable ('slow to adapt') and Dolphin POS. Complex composable architecture creating operational burden. Security vulnerabilities. Fragmented hire/custom-made experience. Board directive to evaluate alternatives.
questions.solution: N/A — well-understood.
questions.action: N/A

questions.text: Have they tried to resolve before?
questions.notes: Invested in Zitec (middleware) and OneStock (inventory) to address data silos. Previously evaluated Shopify but passed due to cost. Board directives now overriding cost objections.
questions.solution: N/A — understood. Position Shopify as next logical step.
questions.action: N/A

questions.text: How do pains affect business operations?
questions.notes: Fragmented hire/custom-made experience across online and POS. Disparate customer management systems. Slow dev velocity on Remarkable. Security risk exposure. Operational complexity. International expansion blocked.
questions.solution: N/A — well-documented.
questions.action: Quantify operational impact for business case where possible.

questions.text: Which teams are affected?
questions.notes: IT/Engineering (Joe, Brett), E-commerce team (Head resistant to change), Retail/POS teams (aging Dolphin), Board/C-suite (strategic concern). No visibility into marketing, merchandising, or store operations impact.
questions.solution: Broaden stakeholder understanding.
questions.action: Maissa to ask Chris which teams beyond IT and e-commerce are most impacted.

questions.text: How urgent is it to solve?
questions.notes: Board has directed evaluation — meaningful urgency. POS replacement is CEO priority. Security adds urgency. But no 'burning platform' deadline. Merchant Intent still 'Uncommitted.'
questions.solution: Help create urgency by quantifying risk of inaction.
questions.action: Include cost-of-delay analysis in executive presentation.

questions.text: Can they solve with another option?
questions.notes: Could extend composable architecture. Other platforms could theoretically address needs. No other vendors currently being evaluated as far as we know.
questions.solution: Understand if other platforms are being considered.
questions.action: Maissa to ask Chris: 'Are you evaluating other platforms or is this Shopify vs. status quo?'

questions.text: Why is solving this important now?
questions.notes: Board directive and CEO/shareholder pressure driving timing. Security incidents raised urgency. International expansion needs better platform. No specific trigger event identified.
questions.solution: Identify harder deadline behind board directive.
questions.action: Probe for contract terms, budget cycles, expansion deadlines.

questions.text: Is Shopify uniquely positioned to solve?
questions.notes: Unified commerce (e-commerce + POS on one platform) is a strong differentiator. AI resonates. However, hire/custom-made and inventory costing are unproven on Shopify. Existing Zitec/OneStock investment narrows the value prop somewhat.
questions.solution: Demonstrate capability for hire, custom-made, and inventory costing.
questions.action: Sarah to ensure demo addresses hire, custom-made, and inventory costing with concrete solutions.

questions.text: Have you identified a true champion?
questions.notes: Chris Turberville-Tully is clearly the champion. Self-described 'Shopify advocate,' actively building business case for CEO, coordinating C-suite presentation, driving internal momentum. Has both motivation and influence.
questions.solution: N/A — champion identified and active.
questions.action: N/A

questions.text: Does champion have political capital?
questions.notes: Chris appears brought in as digital consultant to drive transformation — has a mandate. Direct CEO/CFO access. But Head of E-commerce is resistant. As external consultant, political capital may be limited vs. permanent staff.
questions.solution: Understand power dynamic between Chris and Head of E-commerce.
questions.action: Maissa to ask Chris about Head of E-commerce's role in the decision and their relationship with CEO.

questions.text: Has champion shared insider insights?
questions.notes: Chris provided: company revenue (£160M), internal political dynamics (Head of E-commerce resistance), board risk-aversion, CEO/CFO priorities, implementation partner needs, and willingness to build business case jointly.
questions.solution: N/A — Chris is sharing valuable insider information.
questions.action: Continue nurturing this relationship.

questions.text: Is champion connected to decision-makers?
questions.notes: Chris has direct access to CEO, CFO, and main shareholder. Actively coordinating C-suite presentation and securing dates.
questions.solution: N/A — strong connection confirmed.
questions.action: N/A

questions.text: Have you been introduced to decision-maker?
questions.notes: No direct introduction to CEO, CFO, or shareholder yet. C-suite presentation (early March) will be first direct contact.
questions.solution: Exec presentation is the introduction vehicle.
questions.action: Maissa to prep strong executive presentation tailored to CEO/CFO priorities.

questions.text: Will champion bring you into buying group?
questions.notes: Chris is actively arranging C-suite presentation and committed to securing dates. Planning 1-1.5 hour executive session. Clearly willing to bring Shopify in front of the board.
questions.solution: N/A — confirmed.
questions.action: Ensure presentation is ready and Chris confirms the date.

questions.text: What motivates the champion?
questions.notes: Chris is a 'Shopify advocate' but specific personal motivation not fully clear. Likely: hired as digital consultant to modernize, successful migration enhances his credibility. May have prior Shopify experience.
questions.solution: Understand Chris's personal stakes.
questions.action: Maissa to explore (informally): what does a successful outcome look like for Chris personally?

questions.text: Have you identified all competitors?
questions.notes: Salesforce Competitor field is null. No other vendors mentioned in any calls. Unclear if single-vendor evaluation or others are in parallel.
questions.solution: Directly ask about competitive landscape.
questions.action: Maissa to ask Chris: 'Is Shopify the only platform you're evaluating, or are there others?'

questions.text: Is 'do nothing' a viable competitor?
questions.notes: Not explicitly asked. Board directive suggests 'do nothing' is less likely, but Head of E-commerce resistance could result in status quo if business case isn't compelling enough.
questions.solution: Explicitly explore this.
questions.action: Maissa to ask Chris: 'What happens if the board decides not to move forward?'

questions.text: Are there internal alternatives?
questions.notes: Existing composable architecture could be extended/patched. Head of E-commerce may advocate for this. No explicit mention of building internal solution.
questions.solution: Position Shopify as simplification play vs. continued composable complexity.
questions.action: Ensure business case contrasts TCO of composable vs. consolidating on Shopify.

questions.text: Why are alternatives being evaluated?
questions.notes: Don't know if alternatives are being evaluated. Competitor landscape completely unclear.
questions.solution: Probe the competitive landscape.
questions.action: Same as CO1 — need to understand who else is in the picture.

questions.text: Do we know why we would win or lose?
questions.notes: Win: strong champion, unified commerce vision, AI, POS modernization, board mandate. Lose: complex hire/custom-made requirements, inventory costing gap, Head of E-commerce resistance, risk-averse board, Adyen transition risk, implementation timeline concerns, cost was previously a barrier.
questions.solution: Address lose factors systematically before exec presentation.
questions.action: Create internal deal risk register mapping each lose factor to mitigation plan.

calls.title: Moss Bros x Shopify
calls.ai_summary: Discovery call. Moss explained need to 'uncomplicate their world' and leverage AI within composable architecture (Zitec). Strategic board directives driving evaluation. Past Shopify cost concerns acknowledged. Key questions on weighted inventory costing and POS replacement. Follow-up with Chris Turberville-Tully and SE scheduled.

calls.title: Shopify X Moss - Intro
calls.ai_summary: Intro call. Chris revealed Moss is £160M UK retailer needing to migrate from Remarkable to Shopify (e-commerce + POS) for international expansion and AI. Head of E-commerce is resistant. Chris is Shopify advocate championing to CEO and risk-averse board. Next: technical discovery with IT team, Chris to gather financial drivers from CFO for joint business case.

calls.title: Shopify X Moss - Technical Discovery
calls.ai_summary: Technical discovery evaluating Shopify to replace Remarkable (e-commerce) and Dolphin (POS). Moss has composable architecture with ZITC addressing data silos. Primary concerns: handling 'hire' business (group bookings, deposits) and 'custom-made' models, plus Adyen payment transition. Next: assess complex requirements, address payment logistics, plan tailored demo.

calls.title: Shopify X Moss (Follow-up)
calls.ai_summary: Follow-up on next steps. Chris satisfied with tech session. CEO/CFO priorities: replacing aging POS, security (past incidents), AI. Chris requested case studies and 2-3 implementation partners. Plan: 2-hour demo review with tech team week of Feb 23, then 1-1.5 hour exec presentation early March.

calls.title: Shopify X Moss - Demo Prep
calls.ai_summary: Demo prep session. Joe clarified Zitec/OneStock already handle unified data/inventory. Key interest: consolidating customer management and streamlining custom-made/outfit builder across channels. Challenges flagged: split payment logic, average inventory costing. Critical next step: realistic implementation timeline. Sarah to investigate 'Black Tux' custom solution.
